Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Social change, parasite exposure and immune dysregulation: An evolutionary medicine approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Two recent hypotheses--the Hygiene Hypothesis and the Disappearing Microbiota Hypothesis--argue that the dramatic rise in allergies and autoimmune disorders in industrialized nations stems from decreased exposure to pathogens. These hypotheses posit a mismatch between contemporary lifestyles and the evolved biology of the human species. People living in developed nations such as the United States are experiencing reduced exposure to parasitic worms and bacteria, as well as overall changes to the microbial composition of the gut, compared to individuals living in less developed nations. These changes appear to be resulting in decreased immune stimulation and an increased vulnerability to allergy and autoimmune diseases, which are nearly absent in non-Western populations. The present dissertation study by doctoral student Tara Cepon (University of Oregon), under the supervision of Dr. James Snodgrass, tests both the Hygiene and Disappearing Microbiota Hypotheses among the Shuar, a forager-horticulturalist population from Amazonian Ecuador who are currently experiencing rapid yet uneven cultural change related to integration into the market-based economy.

The project examines relationships among social/lifestyle factors, intestinal parasite composition, and immune function and dysregulation among three geographically separated Shuar communities experiencing different degrees of market involvement and related social change. Through household interviews, microscopic and molecular analyses of fecal samples, and biomarkers of immune function, the present project will shed light on patterns of parasite exposure and the role of humans as ecosystems for our parasitic residents, as well as the contribution that these residents make to immune development and function. This study also will advance knowledge of the health effects of cultural change by focusing needed attention on how environmental shifts affect infectious and autoimmune disease prevalence.

Beyond these contributions, this study has important implications for public health policy, community outreach, international science partnerships, and education. The research increases our understanding of the effects of market-related changes on health variation among Shuar and, by extension, other populations undergoing cultural change. Further, it has the potential to provide insights that can be used for improving local and global health by identifying lifestyle factors to target when implementing policies to reduce infectious and chronic disease burden. Finally, this project will train a female scientist and will provide research opportunities for undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project tests aspects of the Hygiene Hypothesis, which proposes important roles for certain disease-causing agents, like soil-transmitted helminths (STHs; parasitic worms) and bacteria, for regulating the human immune system and preventing the development of allergy and autoimmunity. We collected interview data, dried blood spots (DBS), and fecal samples from 300 Shuar participants in conjunction with the Shuar Health and Life History Project (http://www.bonesandbehavior.org/shuar/). The Shuar are an indigenous forager-horticulturalist group from Amazonian Ecuador who are currently experiencing rapid yet varied integration into regional/global market economies. This varied economic development allows us to test the relationship between STHs and immune function in a way that would be impossible in industrialized populations like the U.S.

Interviews assessed level of market integration (MI; the suite of social/cultural changes associated with participation in and production for market-based economies). Three Style of Life (SOL) variables were created from these interviews related to housing type (SOL House; Figure 1), ownership of market goods (SOL Market), and ownership of items used in traditional subsistence activities (SOL Traditional).

Stool samples were analyzed (Figure 2) for STH prevalence/intensity. These samples were then sequenced for bacterial DNA in the Genomics Laboratory (University of Oregon). Data analysis is underway to test the role of important bacterial species and diversity in immune regulation.

Finger-prick dried blood spots (Figure 3) were analyzed in the Snodgrass Human Biology Research Laboratory (University of Oregon) for three specific biomarkers related to immune function and inflammation: Interleukin-6 (IL-6), C-reactive protein (CRP), and Immunoglobulin E (IgE). Inflammation is important to study in this context. Over an extended period of time, high levels of inflammation can damage the body, resulting a number of chronic conditions like heart disease, diabetes, allergies, and autoimmune disorders. IL-6 and CRP are both associated with chronically elevated inflammation, while IgE is responsible for detecting STHs and allergens. When IgE detects allergens, it triggers an inflammatory response. When IgE encounters STHs, however, it may stimulate anti-inflammatory pathways to turn down inflammation.

Our findings indicate that MI strongly influences STH exposure (Cepon-Robins et al., 2014). The two STH species present among the Shuar were the ascarid (Ascaris lumbricoides; Figure 4) and the whipworm (Trichuris trichiura; Figure 5). Ascarid infection was affected by level of MI, with more integrated communities, and individuals with more integrated homes (higher SOL House) and more market-based items (higher SOL Market) having lower risk for infection and lower infection intensities than their more traditional counterparts.

Both MI and STH exposure were related to disgust sensitivity. Disgust is a universally experienced emotion which may have evolved to protect individuals from exposure to harmful substances and behaviors. In a paper that is currently in preparation, we demonstrate the role of disgust in motivating the avoidance of STH exposure. It appears that disgust sensitivity is heightened in more market integrated individuals, motivating hygiene/sanitation and decreasing STH exposure.

Decreased exposure to STHs may be responsible for irregular immune function.
